{include "affiliate_loader"} Got an absentee ballot? Drop it off, don't mail it. {include "pre-header-spacing"}{beacon}

{include "default_salutation"} –

Most of us believe that, in our American democracy, every vote should count. But now, with Election Day on the horizon, a last-minute ruling could endanger that basic principle for hard-working, fair-minded Minnesota voters. Unless we take action together.

The federal court ruling means that all absentee ballots returned by mail must be received by 8 p.m. on Election Day – even though the Minnesota Secretary of State already agreed to accept ballots postmarked by Election Day and received up to a week later.

What does this ruling mean for Minnesota voters?

First of all, it means that the instructions and deadlines printed on Minnesotans' absentee ballots are no longer accurate. That's why we need our supporters like you to help us get the word out and make sure that every vote cast in Minnesota counts.

It also means that Minnesotans should not return any more ballots by mail. If you have an absentee ballot and have not returned it yet, drop it off or vote in person.

  • Drop your absentee ballot off at your county elections office or at another official drop-off location. (Ballots must be dropped off by 3 p.m. on Election Day at the locations linked above, not an Election Day polling place.)
  • Vote in person, rather than return your absentee ballot. If you have not yet mailed your ballot, simply find your early voting location or Election Day polling place, and go be a voter.

Minnesotans who have mailed their ballot recently must take action to make sure their votes are counted. If you mailed in your ballot recently, there is a chance it will not arrive by Nov. 3. Track your ballot status. If it is not received by Election Day, go to your polling location, tell a poll worker you want to "spoil" your absentee ballot, and cast your vote in person.

The last-minute challenge that led to this ruling is an attack on the most foundational principle of our democracy – that every vote must be counted. But we won't let them have the final say, {include "first_name"}. The final say belongs to us, the voters. And we intend to make our votes count, and our voices heard.

In solidarity,

ACLU of {affiliate_name}
